0.00.text:
In the field, I feel so
connected to everything,

2.80.text:
but then I'd come home and I
would feel so disconnected

6.71.text:
and I started to
hate coming home

11.98.text:
I'd have to sit in this
quietness and feel this pain

15.18.text:
and I didn't know where
it was coming from

16.85.text:
and I felt myself
withdrawing further,

18.79.text:
and I had a beautiful wife
who genuinely loved me,

24.39.text:
but you know, in the field,
I felt like I was in a tribe.

27.86.text: I felt like I was together.

29.80.text:
It was egalitarian, we
cared for each other,

32.43.text:
there was responsibility,
we took care of one another,

36.64.text:
and then I'd come home and
I'd feel completely alone,

40.34.text:
and I'd feel a nothingness,
and I think those elements

45.88.text:
of tribalism are really
important in our lives.

48.01.text: We are better when we are with

54.95.text:
As a group, we are
better together.

61.36.text:
the noise of this urban
life that I'd come back to,

63.30.text:
going to Whole Foods
and have literal...

65.53.text: I could have anything I want.

68.93.text:
What kind of organic
whatever do you want?

72.17.text:
And having just come
home from a place

74.07.text:
where people are out
farming every day.

76.68.text:
I couldn't get over the
noise that I was hearing.

80.08.text:
It was a very distracting
hum and I'd think,

82.75.text:
I'd get up in the
morning and I'd go,

84.15.text:
I can get through the
day today, I got this.

86.82.text:
I don't have to drink
tonight, I can just...

90.76.text:
And by noon, it was so much
that that's when I would,

95.79.text: you know, have my first drink,

99.13.text: and I never drank to get drunk.

101.20.text:
I just drank to calm it down
because I was screaming inside

106.64.text:
and I didn't know
how to stop it,

108.81.text:
because the only places
that helped me were

112.11.text:
the places where
I was distracted,

115.38.text:
I was in the field, and
I was part of a tribe,

118.75.text:
and I couldn't be
disassociated out there.

124.92.text:
and I think it was more to the
point that I felt cared for.

131.20.text:
I'd come home and we'd
gloss over everything

134.17.text:
and there's this
event, this avalanche,

136.74.text:
going back to it started
to appear as the event

141.74.text:
that sparked this great
divide in my life,

144.68.text:
because it had shot me
in one direction upwards.

147.25.text:
My career had taken
off, and yet inside,

153.55.text:
some sort of vacuous rock
bottom that I couldn't define.

157.16.text:
The reason I put this
up here is because

159.19.text:
my wife and I were not
communicating about it.

163.10.text:
There was such a
space between us,

165.36.text:
and I love this shot because
it's so typical of us.

171.37.text:
It's trying to get the
camera above all the (bleep),

175.47.text: just to get the pretty stuff,

177.61.text:
and that's not what
human relationships are.

179.75.text:
That's not what life
is; life is the (bleep).

185.89.text:
and there was too much
distance between us to sustain,

188.32.text:
and I found myself
completely alone.

193.73.text:
Oftentimes surrounded by
people, but completely alone.

198.13.text:
But the best part is, in my
job, there's always a way

199.93.text:
to go distract yourself, so
the next assignment came.

203.70.text:
It was to northern
Burma or Myanmar.

207.07.text:
It's changing at
a very rapid pace.

209.27.text:
My life was changing
at a rapid pace

211.18.text:
and I felt like this
was a perfect way

214.71.text:
I was gonna solve
all the problems.

216.65.text:
This country is steeped
in mystery and antiquity.

220.02.text:
It's one of the most beautiful
landscapes I'd ever seen,

222.82.text:
but the northern regions,
specifically, are...

227.49.text:
They've just emerged from
decades of bloody civil war.

232.37.text:
The northern reaches have
been, the Kachin State has been

235.60.text:
off limits to
outsiders for decades,

238.44.text:
so our access was incredible,
and that's actually

242.34.text:
something we do very well
here, is we get access,

246.18.text:
and that is a very
huge privilege.

252.15.text:
that we would not
otherwise be able to go.

256.42.text:
But it's interesting too,
when I look at my photography

258.99.text:
on this trip, specifically
in urban environments,

263.93.text:
I was running so hard from
everything that was happening

269.54.text:
in my life, it was pushing me
outward with my photography,

272.64.text: and I was trying to get closer

274.74.text: and I was trying to be more bold

277.21.text:
and I was getting more
and more in people's faces,

279.55.text:
and I thought it was
because I was able

281.98.text:
to get away from all
that pain, and in fact,

284.28.text:
I think it was because I
was carrying it with me

286.25.text:
and they recognized,
I think, when we bring

288.79.text:
our baggage with us,
people recognize that.

291.89.text:
It's a non-verbal
thing, but people say,

294.63.text:
okay, this person's
human and they let you

296.56.text:
into your space in a
much more profound way.

299.06.text:
When you are equal, when
you are not a different guy,

302.77.text:
you know, you're not the white
dude with the big camera,

305.34.text:
you're the broken guy
who hurts all day,

309.48.text:
they're like, oh,
give him a shot.

315.92.text:
The point of the trip
was to go overland

320.12.text:
to measure the highest
point in southeast Asia.

323.29.text:
We were trying to solve this
big geographical mystery

326.69.text:
that had been
created by the war.

328.66.text:
The war creates
holes in the map.

330.66.text:
If you can't go there and
modern science hasn't gone there

333.50.text:
for decades, how are we
gonna know what exists there?

336.84.text:
So we were actually mapping
and trying to measure

339.27.text:
the highest point
in southeast Asia.

342.74.text:
Like I said, it was
an overland journey

344.54.text:
and we were going first
by overnight buses.

349.98.text:
It was great, like
it was amazing.

352.42.text:
First, the bus barely starts,
then all the seats are full,

356.69.text:
and then you're like,
oh, that's pretty packed.

358.32.text: Like, three people to two seats,

360.79.text:
and then they start bringing
in the little chairs

364.53.text:
that you put your kids
in at the kids' table

367.30.text:
and they just put 'em down the
aisle, right in the middle,

370.24.text:
and they get full grown
men to sit down in those.

374.44.text:
Don't try to go to the
bathroom; it doesn't work.

378.18.text:
Then we took a 24 hour
boat up the Irrawaddy River

383.48.text:
We took what's called
the death train.

387.12.text:
It's a train that
hasn't been cared for

389.32.text:
since the British left,
so you're literally,

396.30.text:
It's like 24 hours
of waiting for death,

399.90.text:
so if the avalanche
didn't traumatize me,
I'm sure that did.

402.87.text:
At least my back
was almost broken.

404.74.text:
I had about 50 spider
bites on my leg

407.44.text:
when I got off
the train somehow,

410.61.text:
and finally, planes, and then
the last form of movement

416.18.text:
that we were taking
were motorbikes,

419.18.text:
and we were gonna
take motorbikes 80
miles into the jungle

421.92.text:
before we started our walk,
and these guys were awesome.

424.09.text:
As the rider called them,
the Baby's Hell's Angels,

428.79.text:
well actually, because
their bikes are tiny

430.86.text:
but they were pretty
awesome, they were legit.

433.60.text:
One morning, I
remember waking up

435.67.text:
and the bikes are loaded,
overloaded, really,

438.84.text: and this one guy grabs a beer.

440.84.text:
It's like seven; it's
fine, no judgment.

443.34.text:
I've done it, you know,
we're talking about this.

445.51.text:
Let's be honest,
and cracks his beer

449.78.text: and then he pours some out.

452.22.text:
I'm like, that's cool,
some for the homies, good.

456.36.text:
No, then he takes a
little bottle of whiskey

459.53.text: and just fills it back up.

462.19.text:
I'm like, I'm riding
with that dude

467.27.text:
Anyway, I did ride
with that dude that day

469.54.text:
and as soon as his bike
fell over with me on it,

471.74.text:
I was trying to take pictures
falling off the side,

474.04.text:
but then we decided, well,
now that we're done with this,

476.88.text:
let's walk into the
jungle for 150 miles.

479.81.text:
For those of you who haven't
walked through a jungle,

482.65.text: you don't need to, it's fine.

484.05.text:
Stay home, don't
do it, it's awful.

486.99.text:
It's like walking inside
a green ping pong ball,

492.86.text:
which is cool, you can get
some neat images, kind of,

495.86.text:
but it's very monotonous
and it provides you

497.43.text:
with a lot of time to think,
and what do I do when I think?

500.37.text:
I get super uncomfortable
because I have to focus

504.07.text: on what's happening in my life.

507.34.text: It was a long, long walk,

509.61.text:
and I started to think about
some real serious things.

515.18.text:
But sometimes I could get
distracted by crossing

516.58.text:
bamboo bridges that
have zero metal on them.

523.92.text:
Three people could
cross at a time

529.26.text:
We couldn't see the
mountains at all.

533.70.text:
It was one of the craziest
walks I've ever done

539.01.text:
and literally, if you fall
here, you're just gonna die.

542.17.text:
It's like the most dangerous
walking you've ever done,

545.28.text:
which feels so silly, but
there's still no mountains.

554.29.text:
We'd get to these villages
and I was so amazed.

559.89.text:
I was taken back to one of the
very first photos I showed,

562.93.text:
of the woman sleeping
on the bench.

566.00.text:
We think of that life as so
wrong, and yet these people,

570.30.text:
that is their life, every
day, and yet they've managed

574.07.text:
to deal with it in a
much different way.

576.08.text:
This place is untouched,
except by war.

580.05.text:
There's no roads here,
there's no helicopters.

582.78.text:
There's no medical,
no dentist, no store.

584.92.text:
You need food? You kill
it or you harvest it.

588.12.text:
You need medical? You
pray or you figure it out

592.26.text: or you get sick or you die.

595.93.text:
I mean, there is no help,
and I was taken by that.

601.50.text:
The self reliance is
something we've lost.

605.17.text:
And then after 30 days of
walking, 150 miles of walking,

612.75.text:
We'd walked through the
thick, dense rainforest

615.78.text:
and then we got to the deciduous
trees and then the pines

618.28.text:
and then all of a sudden,
we're into the rhododendrons

620.25.text:
and we can't see anything,
and then all of a sudden,

623.19.text:
the day before the
mountain, it just pops up,

626.53.text:
and it's right on the edge
of the Tibetan plateau.

629.73.text: It sort of rose out of mystery.

632.20.text:
We were kinda like, is there
really a mountain here?

636.94.text:
Climbing a mountain by a
new route is interesting

641.44.text:
People are like, well,
you just go to the top,

645.21.text:
Getting to the top
is not a clear thing

647.81.text:
and I love that because
that is just like life.

650.28.text:
I talked about
that as I started.

654.22.text:
We think of things
as very linear, but
things aren't linear,

658.42.text:
and when we put ourselves
in that linear box,

662.90.text:
We made all sorts
of wrong turns.

665.06.text:
We'd climb up, we'd realize
we were cliffed out.

669.53.text:
We blew hours trying
to figure things out,

672.87.text:
and you know, it's
those ups and downs

675.34.text:
that actually makes the
climbing somewhat worth it,

678.01.text:
because you're
learning as you go.

679.81.text: Every time you make a mistake,

681.45.text:
hopefully, as in life,
you learn from it.

683.75.text:
Finally, we got to our high
point where we had to decide

688.69.text: who was gonna go for the summit

690.22.text: because we were a team of five

691.79.text:
and only three could
really climb above this,

694.49.text:
and we made the decision
and it splintered our team.

700.07.text:
It was very high stakes at
this point, but we had to make

702.97.text:
a decision of the most
suited climbers to go,

705.54.text:
because the climbing
above is like this,

713.18.text:
compared to some of the other
stuff that we were doing,

715.55.text:
which is interesting because
you see the rope there.

718.05.text:
That just makes sure
you don't die alone,

720.95.text: so let that sit in for a second.

730.33.text:
That's just there
to kill everybody

732.26.text:
because if you fall,
nothing's gonna...

738.44.text: We were on the north side.

740.14.text:
Renan was losing
feeling in his toes.

746.38.text: we popped over into the sun

748.51.text:
and we saw the summit
for the first time.

756.69.text:
He's not just chilling in
the sun; he's that tired,

759.89.text:
and I was elated to see
that ridge ahead of us,

763.20.text:
until I realized
there was no way

766.36.text: that we were gonna climb that.

768.13.text:
We kept going, 'cause you
have to try, you have to try,

772.00.text:
but in my brain, it
was so convoluted.

775.37.text:
It was so confusing, and
I just didn't think we had

779.04.text:
the power to make it, and
sure enough, we turned around.

782.55.text:
We turned around at
that point of snow

788.32.text:
so we were very
close to the top,

790.26.text:
but the idea was,
well, is this worth it?

792.36.text:
Because if we keep going,
we're likely gonna die,

794.66.text: and if we die, that's not gonna

796.33.text:
make anybody back
home very happy.

799.57.text:
We were too tired,
and we failed.

802.50.text:
This is us returning
to high camp,

804.27.text:
letting it sink in
that we had just failed

806.34.text:
on this huge expedition
for National Geographic

811.28.text:
is there actual value
in this failure?

813.85.text:
I think there is; I think
there's value in all failure.

819.52.text:
Only when you surrender to
it can you learn from it.

822.89.text:
Only when you give
yourself over to it

825.09.text: can you learn for the next time.

827.36.text:
We failed to bring enough
rolling papers for the tobacco,

836.50.text:
out of a book called Finding
George Orwell in Burma,

840.81.text:
and that's what Renan
is smoking there.

845.24.text:
That's actually a
map of the exact

847.05.text:
region we were in,
which is great.

849.01.text:
We're just like, we're done
with this, burn it down.

855.35.text: But I also knew that coming out,

857.62.text:
this was the trip
where I realized,

859.29.text: with all that time to think,

860.79.text:
that there were a lot
more failures ahead of me.

863.09.text:
I was just beginning that, and
it was the trip where I knew

866.10.text:
that, you know, my
marriage was over.

871.17.text:
There was no way to
reconcile what had happened.

876.38.text:
My despondence had
pulled us apart.

879.58.text:
My confusion, my aloneness,
my unwillingness to engage,

886.12.text:
my inability to engage
had pulled us apart.

889.25.text:
I was so disconnected, and that
disconnectedness had created

892.62.text:
a void, and a void that I had
filled with anything I could,

896.53.text:
whether on assignment
or at home,

898.70.text: whether it was alcohol or women.

902.53.text:
I'm just gonna be
honest with you guys.

905.07.text:
I cheated and I lied
and I was a bad husband.

911.18.text:
and I was trying so hard to
figure out, how could I be

916.58.text:
a good person and a bad
person at the same time

918.72.text:
and I was ripped apart and
I did all the things wrong,

922.79.text:
and those actions,
they have consequences,

925.86.text:
and those consequences can
hurt, and it really, really hurt

934.70.text:
and that put me in a
very strange place.

942.81.text:
But I also started seeing
differently with my photography.

945.71.text:
I was looking for different
things, because I wanted to find

949.55.text:
a way out of what I was
feeling, and yet I felt like

952.85.text:
I was getting further
and further sucked in

955.39.text:
because this was how I left
the house the last time,

959.99.text:
and that's a really, really
hard image to look at.

963.76.text:
It's not something
I like to remember,

965.56.text:
but it's something that's
important to talk about.
